This is a serious condition that can lead to tooth loss if left untreated. It is caused by a build-up of plaque and tartar on the teeth, resulting in inflammation and infection of the gums.

Painkillers and regular brushing will not be enough to treat this infection. It is important that you see a dental professional for a proper examination and treatment plan. They may prescribe antibiotics to help clear up the infection, and they will also thoroughly clean your teeth and gums to remove any build-up of plaque and tartar. In some cases, surgery may be necessary to fully treat the infection.

The recovery time for gum infections can vary, but with proper treatment and good oral hygiene, it is possible to make a full recovery. It is important to continue taking care of your oral health by brushing at least twice a day and flossing daily to prevent future infections.

I highly recommend scheduling an appointment with your dentist as soon as possible to address your gum infection and start treatment. I hope you find relief from your pain soon. Take care.

Again, it is important to consult with a pediatrician for a proper diagnosis and treatment plan. They may also recommend certain medications to help manage your baby's symptoms. Varicose veins are a common condition that can affect any part of the body, including the scrotum. It occurs when the veins become enlarged, twisted, and painful. The condition can be caused by a variety of factors, such as genetics, obesity, pregnancy, and standing for long periods.

To help alleviate your husband's varicose veins, there are a few things he can do. First, he should try to avoid standing for long periods and take breaks to sit and rest his legs. He can also try elevating his legs while resting or sleeping. Wearing compression stockings can also help improve circulation and prevent the veins from swelling.

In terms of medication, fertiflax and paternia tablets may help with fertility, but they are not specifically targeted for varicose veins. However, your husband can try taking over-the-counter nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) to help with the pain and discomfort. It is important to consult with a doctor before giving any medication.

In some cases, surgery may be necessary to treat varicose veins. This can include procedures such as sclerotherapy, where a solution is injected into the affected veins to shrink them, or laser therapy, where a laser is used to close the veins. If your husband's varicose veins are severe, he may need to undergo surgery to remove the affected veins. It is best to consult with a doctor to determine the best course of treatment for his specific situation.

144: The correct answer is b. Alpha motor neurons are activated before gamma motor neurons. Alpha motor neurons are responsible for initiating and controlling muscle contraction, and are typically activated first during voluntary movement. Gamma motor neurons, on the other hand, are involved in fine-tuning muscle contraction and are activated after alpha motor neurons during heavy activity. However, during light activity, both alpha and gamma motor neurons may be activated at the same time.

Hello Jamini,

Thank you for reaching out. I understand your concerns for your mother's health. Let me provide some insights regarding your situation.

Firstly, an ultrasound report shows a normal result, which means there may not be any major concerns. However, a follow-up FNAC test is necessary to confirm the diagnosis and determine the type of tumor, whether benign or non-benign.

FNAC or Fine Needle Aspiration Cytology is a minimally invasive procedure that involves extracting cells from the tumor using a thin needle. It is a safe and accurate way to diagnose the nature of the tumor and determine the best course of treatment.

Regarding your friend's statement, it is important to note that FNAC does not spread the tumor. The needle used is very fine and the cells are extracted from a specific area, therefore minimizing the risk of spreading to other parts of the body. It is a routine procedure used by medical professionals to diagnose tumors and is considered safe.

I would strongly recommend following your doctor's advice and going for the FNAC test. It is a crucial step in determining the appropriate treatment for your mother and should not be delayed. If the tumor is indeed non-benign, early detection and treatment can greatly increase the chances of recovery.

Based on the information provided, here is an explanation of the different measurements in the carotid ultrasound report:

1. PS/ED Velocity: This refers to the peak systolic (PS) and end diastolic (ED) velocity of blood flow in the carotid artery. It is measured in centimeters per second (cm/sec) and is used to assess the speed and regularity of blood flow in the carotid artery.

2. Distal CCA: The Distal Common Carotid Artery (CCA) is a section of the carotid artery close to the carotid bifurcation (where the artery splits into the internal and external carotid arteries). The measurement provided (65/9 cm/sec) indicates the peak systolic/end diastolic velocities in this particular area.

3. Max ICA: The Internal Carotid Artery (ICA) is one of the main branches of the carotid artery and supplies blood to the brain. The measurement provided (84/24 cm/sec) refers to the peak systolic/end diastolic velocities in this section of the ICA.

4. ECA: The External Carotid Artery (ECA) is another main branch of the carotid artery and supplies blood to the face and neck. The measurement provided (87/13 cm/sec) refers to the peak systolic/end diastolic velocities in this section of the ECA.

To confirm the diagnosis, your doctor likely ordered an MRI and EEG to rule out any other possible causes of the head pain. The good news is that both of these tests came back normal, meaning your child's brain is functioning normally.

However, the treatment for automastoiditis is a long course of antibiotics, typically 6 weeks to 3 months, to completely clear the infection. If the infection does not clear with antibiotics, your child may need to undergo surgery to drain the infected fluid.

The worst case scenario is that the infection may spread to other areas of the body or cause complications such as meningitis. However, with proper treatment, this is usually not a concern.

Jaundice is a condition in which the skin, eyes, and other mucous membranes turn yellow due to a high level of bilirubin in the blood. Bilirubin is a yellow pigment that is produced when old red blood cells are broken down in the liver.

The enlarged liver and spleen, blood in the stool, thin blood, and heart murmur are all indications of a possible underlying liver disease. The liver is responsible for filtering out bilirubin from the blood, and when it is not functioning properly, it can lead to a buildup of bilirubin in the body.

Hello, thank you for reaching out. I am sorry to hear about the loss of your brother and sister-in-law's son.

In regards to your question about the possibility of having a third child through a reversible tubectomy, there are a few things to keep in mind. First, it is important to understand that tubectomy, also known as tubal ligation, is a permanent form of birth control. Therefore, the success rate of reversing it is not guaranteed.

The procedure your wife underwent in 2007 is called a tubal ligation, which involves blocking or cutting the fallopian tubes to prevent pregnancy. Reversing this procedure is called tubal reanastomosis and involves reconnecting the fallopian tubes to allow for the passage of eggs and sperm.

The success rate of tubal reanastomosis varies depending on factors such as the type of tubal ligation performed, the length of the remaining fallopian tubes, and the amount of scar tissue. Generally, the success rate ranges from 40-90%, but it is lower for women over 35 years old.

In order to determine if tubal reanastomosis is a possibility and to assess the likelihood of success, your wife will need to undergo a thorough evaluation by a fertility specialist. This may include physical exams, blood tests, and imaging tests. It is also important to discuss the risks and possible complications of the procedure with your doctor.

As a doctor, it is important to understand that each patient's condition and pain management plan can vary. It is difficult to determine specific medication recommendations without a thorough evaluation. That being said, pain management physicians typically focus on addressing chronic pain and improving quality of life through a multidisciplinary approach that may include medications, physical therapy, injections, and other non-pharmacological treatments.

Some common types of medications that a pain management physician may prescribe for chronic pain include nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) such as ibuprofen or naproxen, muscle relaxants, antidepressants, and anticonvulsants. These medications can help reduce pain and improve function in individuals with scoliosis or hip pain.

It is important to note that the use of opioid medications, such as hydrocodone or Tramadol, for chronic pain is controversial and should be carefully considered and closely monitored due to the potential for dependence, abuse, and other adverse effects.

If you are unable to afford physical therapy, your pain management physician may also recommend other non-pharmacological treatments such as heat or cold therapy, transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS), or spinal manipulation.

It is important to follow up with your pain management physician and discuss your treatment options and any concerns you may have about medication management. With the help of your healthcare team, you can work together to develop a personalized pain management plan that is safe and effective for you.

Hello, as a professional doctor, I can provide information and guidance but please note that I cannot give a definitive answer without personally examining you and your condition.

Asthma is a chronic respiratory condition that causes inflammation and narrowing of the airways, making it difficult to breathe. It can be triggered by various factors, including exercise, cold air, chemicals, and exposure to smoke.

Moving away from an environment with smokers is definitely a positive step in managing your asthma. However, for some people, asthma can still persist even without direct exposure to smoke. Factors such as genetics, allergies, and respiratory infections can also play a role.

The severity of asthma symptoms and how long they last can vary from person to person. Some people experience milder symptoms and may even have long periods of time without any symptoms. In others, asthma can be a lifelong condition.

There is no cure for asthma, but it can be effectively managed with the right treatment plan. This may include medications to control inflammation and open up the airways, as well as avoiding triggers and making lifestyle changes.

It is important to work closely with your doctor to develop an individualized treatment plan that addresses your specific triggers and symptoms. With proper management, it is possible for asthma to be well controlled and have minimal impact on your life.

I hope this information helps and I encourage you to continue working with your doctor to find the best treatment plan for your asthma. There is definitely hope for managing and improving your condition.

Zurig 80mg is a medication used to treat high levels of uric acid, which can cause gout and kidney stones. It works by decreasing the production of uric acid in the body. The usual dosage for this medication is 80mg once daily and again, it is important to follow your doctor's instructions.

Elevated ALT levels can indicate liver damage or inflammation, which can be caused by various factors such as viral infections, alcohol use, or medication. The normal range for ALT is 5-40 units per liter (U/L), so a level of 90 U/L would be considered high.

The symptoms you are describing, such as sneezing, irritation in the ears, and flu-like syndrome, could be indicative of allergic rhinitis. Allergic rhinitis is a condition where your nose becomes inflamed due to an allergic response to certain triggers, such as cold temperatures or strong smells. It is a common condition that affects many people and can be managed with various treatment options.

The prolonged consequences of allergic rhinitis can include persistent symptoms, reduced quality of life, and the development of other related conditions, such as sinusitis or asthma. It is important to manage your symptoms and treat the condition effectively to prevent any potential complications.

Treatment for allergic rhinitis typically involves avoiding triggers, using medications such as antihistamines or nasal sprays, and possibly immunotherapy for more severe cases. You can also try using a saline nasal rinse or wearing a mask when exposed to triggers to reduce your symptoms.

It is always recommended to consult with a doctor for a proper diagnosis and individualized treatment plan. Other conditions that may have similar symptoms include non-allergic rhinitis or sinus infections, so it is important to rule out other possibilities.

In summary, your symptoms may be indicative of allergic rhinitis, a common condition that can be managed with various treatment options. In your case, your doctor may have prescribed Fefol-z to help with your irregular periods and to prepare your body for pregnancy. First, it is important to understand the nature of these tests. HBsAg stands for hepatitis B surface antigen, and it indicates if you have the hepatitis B virus in your body. Anti-Hbs stands for hepatitis B surface antibody, and it indicates that you have been vaccinated against hepatitis B, or that you have recovered from a past infection.

Since you are a nurse, it is highly recommended that you have a thorough understanding of these tests and their implications. You should also inform your employer about your status, as they may have specific policies and procedures in place for employees with HBsAg or anti-Hbs reactivity.

Additionally, it is important to practice standard precautions, such as hand hygiene and the use of personal protective equipment, to prevent the transmission of any infectious diseases. As a healthcare professional, it is your responsibility to protect yourself and your patients from potential harm.

I also advise you to regularly check in with your healthcare provider and monitor your liver function, as individuals with HBsAg reactivity may have an increased risk for certain liver complications.

Dizziness and vertigo can be caused by a variety of factors, including inner ear problems, medications, or underlying medical conditions. The fact that your physician is considering demyelination as a possible cause is likely related to your symptoms of headaches and nausea, as well as the MRI scan being ordered.

Demyelination is a process where the protective covering of nerve cells, called myelin, is damaged or destroyed. This can lead to issues with nerve communication, which can manifest as various neurological symptoms, such as dizziness and vertigo. Leprosy, also known as Hansen's disease, is a chronic infectious disease caused by the bacteria Mycobacterium leprae. It mainly affects the skin, nerves, and mucous membranes of the respiratory tract. The most common symptom of leprosy is the appearance of skin lesions or white spots, which can be flat or raised, on different parts of the body.

In terms of heredity, leprosy is transmissible from person to person, but it is not considered a strongly hereditary disease. This means that having a family member with leprosy does not necessarily mean that you will also develop the disease. However, certain genetic factors can increase the susceptibility to leprosy, such as having a specific immune response to the bacteria.

To determine if a person has leprosy or not, a medical examination and skin biopsy may be conducted by a healthcare professional. The diagnosis is usually confirmed by observing the characteristic skin lesions and the presence of acid-fast bacilli (AFB) in the skin biopsy.

Leprosy is treatable with antibiotics, and early detection and treatment can prevent permanent disability and reduce the risk of transmission to others. The treatment typically involves a combination of antibiotics taken for several months. I would highly recommend consulting a dermatologist

Australia antigen, also known as the hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg), is a protein found on the surface of the hepatitis B virus. The first step in treatment for this infection is to determine the level of viral activity and whether or not the infection is acute (newly acquired) or chronic (ongoing).

Treatment for acute HBV infection may include supportive care such as rest, adequate hydration, and a healthy diet. In some cases, antiviral medication may be prescribed to help the body fight off the infection.

For chronic HBV infection, treatment may include antiviral medications such as entecavir, tenofovir, or interferon alpha. These medications work by suppressing the replication of the virus, helping to reduce the viral load and potential damage to the liver. Treatment may also include liver function monitoring and regular screenings for liver cancer.

Preventive measures for Australia antigen include getting vaccinated against hepatitis B, practicing safe sex, avoiding sharing needles or other drug injection equipment, and taking precautions when handling bodily fluids of others. It is also important for those who are at risk to undergo routine screening for HBV infection.

I hope this information helps. If you have any further concerns or questions, please do not hesitate to reach out to me. Take care.

Dear .j. and .q,

Thank you for reaching out and expressing your concerns. It is important to remember that self-diagnosis can be unreliable and it is always best to seek a professional opinion. Obsessive-impulsive behavior is indeed a known mental disorder. It is called Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD) and is characterized by recurring, unwanted thoughts (obsessions) and repetitive behaviors (compulsions). These obsessions and compulsions can often interfere with daily functioning and cause distress. If you are experiencing these symptoms, I highly recommend seeking a consultation with a mental health professional for proper evaluation and treatment.

As for your question about why farts are smelly, this is a completely normal bodily function. Farts are a result of gas build up in the digestive system and are composed of mostly odorless gases. The smell comes from small amounts of sulfur-containing gases such as hydrogen sulfide and methanethiol. These gases are produced by bacteria in the large intestine as they break down food. Occasionally, a change in diet or certain foods can make farts smell stronger, but it is generally nothing to worry about. 

I hope this answers your questions and thank you for your time and thought in this matter as well. Take care. 

Sincerely, 
[Your Name]

I am sorry to hear that your son is experiencing this problem. It sounds like he may be dealing with a condition called Mal de Debarquement Syndrome (MdDS), which is characterized by a feeling of continuous motion even when there is no actual movement. It is often triggered by a prolonged exposure to motion such as a boat or plane ride, but it can also occur spontaneously.

The exact cause of MdDS is not fully understood, but it is believed to involve a disruption of the body's vestibular system, which is responsible for balance and spatial orientation. This can lead to a mismatch between information received from the eyes and inner ear, resulting in feelings of dizziness and motion sickness.

While there is no specific cure for MdDS, there are treatment options available that can help reduce symptoms and improve quality of life. These may include vestibular rehabilitation therapy, medication, and cognitive-behavioral therapy. However, it is important for your son to undergo a thorough evaluation and diagnosis by a neurologist or otolaryngologist to confirm this condition and determine the best course of treatment for his specific case.

In the meantime, it may also be helpful for your son to avoid triggers such as prolonged motion or bright lights, get adequate rest, and practice relaxation techniques. Dyskinesia refers to a group of movement disorders that are characterized by abnormal, involuntary movements, such as jerking, twisting, or abnormal postures. These movements can occur in different parts of the body, including the face, hands, arms, or legs. The causes of dyskinesia can vary and may be due to certain medications (such as antipsychotics), neurological disorders (such as Parkinson's disease or Huntington's disease), or brain injuries.

Treatment for dyskinesia depends on the underlying cause. If it is medication-induced, your doctor may adjust or change your medication to alleviate the symptoms. In cases where the dyskinesia is caused by a neurological disorder, treatment will focus on managing the underlying condition.

Unfortunately, there is currently no cure for dyskinesia. However, treatments can help to reduce the severity of symptoms and improve quality of life.

There are other conditions that can have similar symptoms to dyskinesia, such as tremors (involuntary shaking) in Parkinson's disease, or tics (sudden, repetitive movements) in Tourette syndrome. It is important to consult with a healthcare professional for an accurate diagnosis and to determine the best course of treatment.

As for your experience of being unaware of your body's movements, it is possible for individuals with dyskinesia to have this lack of awareness, as the movements are involuntary and not under conscious control. It is important to continue working with your healthcare team

There are a few potential reasons for why you may experience a decrease in blood sugar after consuming a sugary snack or dessert. One possibility is that your body is producing more insulin in response to the sudden increase in blood sugar from the sugary food. Insulin is responsible for transporting glucose (sugar) from the blood into cells for energy, which can cause a temporary decrease in blood sugar levels.

Additionally, some individuals with diabetes may experience delayed gastric emptying, which means that food is not quickly digested and absorbed into the bloodstream. In this case, the sugary snack may be moving more slowly through your digestive system, leading to a delayed increase in blood sugar levels and a decrease later on.

It's also important to consider the type and amount of carbohydrates in the sugary food you are consuming. Foods that are higher in simple sugars can cause a more rapid increase in blood sugar, but as the body works to regulate these levels, there may be a temporary decrease.

If you are concerned about your blood sugar levels and how they are affected by sugary foods, it's important to speak with your healthcare provider. They can help you monitor your blood sugar and determine the best diet and management plan for your diabetes.

The main treatment for hemochromatosis is to reduce the amount of iron in the body. This can be done by regularly donating blood. Reducing the intake of iron-rich foods, such as red meat and shellfish, is also recommended. It's great to hear that your son is already following these recommendations.

In addition to these lifestyle changes, your son may also benefit from taking iron-chelating medications. These medications bind to excess iron in the body and help to remove it. I would recommend discussing this option with your son's doctor.

As for a cure, unfortunately, there is no cure for hemochromatosis. However, with proper management and treatment, many people with this condition can live normal, healthy lives.

2399:
There are a few reasons why we do not currently use treatments like kidney dialysis to remove cancer cells from the body. 

Firstly, cancer cells are not all located in one specific area of the body like the kidneys are. They can be found throughout the body and removing all of them through a filtration process like dialysis would be extremely difficult and potentially harmful to the patient. 

Secondly, cancer cells are constantly multiplying and changing, making it difficult to pinpoint a specific genetic code or flaw to target with a treatment. While we do know some genetic mutations that are commonly found in cancer cells, each individual's cancer is unique and may not have the same mutations.

Lastly, cancer cells are not the only cells in our body that require energy from food to survive. While we may be able to target cancer cells with a poison or starvation method, it would also harm healthy cells and potentially cause severe side effects for the patient. 

There are many different treatments for cancer currently available, including chemotherapy and targeted therapies that aim to specifically target cancer cells while minimizing harm to healthy cells. While the idea of targeting cancer cells with outside the body treatments may seem appealing, it is not currently a viable or safe option.

The spleen is an organ located under the ribcage on the left side of the body. Its main function is to filter and store blood, and to contribute to the body's immune system by producing and storing white blood cells, particularly those that fight against bacteria and viruses. 
A person can live without a spleen, but it does put them at a slightly higher risk for certain types of infections. The spleen also helps to filter out damaged or old red blood cells, so without it, a person may have a slightly higher risk of developing anemia. However, the body has mechanisms to compensate for the absence of a spleen, and most people who have had their spleen removed lead healthy and normal lives. 
It is important to make sure to keep up with regular check-ups and vaccinations, as well as avoiding exposure to potentially harmful infections. I hope this information helps. Take care.

I understand your concerns about your 22-month-old not wanting to eat. It is common for toddlers to go through periods where they are picky eaters. However, if your child's weight is not increasing, it is important to address this with her pediatrician. They can assess her growth and provide personalized recommendations for her dietary needs.

In the meantime, here are some general tips for encouraging a toddler to eat:

1. Offer a variety of healthy and nutritious foods. Include different textures and colors to make mealtime more interesting and appealing.

2. Make mealtime fun and interactive. Involve your child in meal preparation and let them help choose what they want to eat from a few healthy options.

3. Be patient and do not force your child to eat. This can create negative associations with food and make them even more resistant to eating.

4. Offer small, frequent meals throughout the day. Young children have small stomachs and may not be able to eat large portions at once.

5. Avoid distractions during mealtime, such as TV or toys. Encourage your child to focus on their food and the social aspect of eating with the family.

The cribriform plate is a thin bone that separates the brain from the nasal cavity, and it appears to have a defect measuring 5mm. This defect has allowed for the meninges (protective covering of the brain), subarachnoid space, and part of the olfactory tract and gyrus rectus (brain structures involved in smell) to herniate or protrude into the nasal cavity. There may also be a smaller defect in the roof of the right frontal sinus, allowing for herniation of meninges and potentially affecting the basi frontal region (front part of the brain).

In addition, your brother may be experiencing bilateral sensorineural hearing loss, meaning the hearing loss is due to damage in the inner ear or nerve pathways. This may be a result of the skull fracture and subsequent meningocoele.

It is important that your brother undergo further evaluation and treatment, as this condition can lead to complications such as infection, brain damage, and further hearing loss. Angina is a type of chest pain that occurs when there is reduced blood flow to the heart, usually due to narrowed or blocked coronary arteries. This can happen at any age, although it is more common among older adults.

Since you mentioned that you are anaemic, it is important to note that anemia can also contribute to worsening angina symptoms. Anemia is a condition in which there is a decrease in red blood cells or hemoglobin, resulting in reduced oxygen supply to the body. This can worsen chest pain and fatigue, especially during physical activity.

I'm glad to hear that the glycerol trinitrate spray provided relief for your symptoms. However, it is important to follow up with your GP and get a proper evaluation, including an electrocardiogram (ECG) and possibly a stress test, to determine the underlying cause of your chest pain. It is concerning that the hospital did not accept your referral, but your GP may be able to refer you to a different facility or specialist for further evaluation.

In the meantime, it is important to take care of your overall health by following a balanced diet, staying hydrated, and avoiding strenuous activities until your symptoms are properly evaluated. Please consult with your doctor if you experience any worsening of symptoms or new symptoms.

One possibility is that the blood vessels in the nose are weakened due to chronic high blood pressure, making them more prone to bleeding. Another possibility is that the high blood pressure is causing the blood vessels in the nose to become engorged and burst, leading to nosebleeds. It is also possible that the medication your mother is taking for her high blood pressure is causing her nosebleeds as a side effect.

I would recommend that your mother schedule an appointment with her primary care physician or a specialist, such as an ear, nose, and throat (ENT) doctor, for a thorough evaluation and proper diagnosis. If the nosebleeds are severe or persist despite these measures, seeking immediate medical attention is advised.

Based on the description provided, it is difficult to give a definite diagnosis without examining the lump or performing any tests. However, there are a few possibilities that could explain the lump:

1. Lipoma: Lipomas are benign (non-cancerous) growths of fat cells under the skin. They are usually painless and can occur anywhere on the body. They often feel soft and rubbery and can be easily moved under the skin.

2. Cyst: A cyst is a sac-like structure filled with fluid or semi-solid material. They can also occur anywhere on the body and are usually painless. However, if a cyst becomes infected, it can cause pain and inflammation, which could explain the brown color and tenderness of the lump.

3. Abscess: An abscess is an infected area of tissue that forms a pocket of pus under the skin. They can be caused by bacteria entering through a cut or wound and often appear as a painful, swollen lump that is red and warm to the touch.

4. Inflamed hair follicle: It is possible that the lump is an inflamed hair follicle or an ingrown hair. These can occur in areas where hair is present and may cause pain and discoloration similar to what you have described.

I would recommend consulting with a doctor to have the lump evaluated and potentially undergo a biopsy or imaging studies to provide a more accurate diagnosis. It is important to keep an eye on the lump for any changes in size

At the hospital, your mother will most likely receive intravenous fluids and insulin to bring down her blood sugar levels and correct the acid imbalance in her body. The medical team will also closely monitor her heart function and may order additional tests, such as a cardiac catheterization, to assess her heart health.

It is important for your mother to receive proper treatment for DKA as soon as possible to prevent further complications. If her blood sugar levels continue to fluctuate, she may also need to be placed on a continuous insulin infusion (insulin drip) for better control.

In the long term, it is essential for your mother to closely manage her diabetes with medication, diet, and exercise to prevent future episodes of DKA. It is also important for her to regularly monitor her blood sugar levels and seek immediate medical attention if she experiences any symptoms of DKA again.

The progression from the prior study indicates that the condition has worsened over time.

2. What is cholelithiasis and acute cholecystitis? 
Cholelithiasis is the medical term for gallstones, which are solid deposits of bile and other substances that form in the gallbladder. Acute cholecystitis is a sudden inflammation of the gallbladder, often caused by a blockage from gallstones.

A stable renal cyst means that it has not grown or changed since the prior study. This is a positive finding, as it indicates that the cysts are not causing any issues or complications.

Based on the results of your semen analysis, there are several normal and abnormal points that can affect fertility. 

Normal points: 
1. Color: Creamy white is a normal color for semen.
2. Aspect: Slightly viscid or thick consistency is normal for semen.
3. Volume: 6 ml is a normal volume for semen. 
4. Total sperm count: 77.1 mil/ml is considered a normal range for sperm count.
5. Sperm motility: Having at least 1 hour of 75% motility is considered normal.
6. White blood cells (WBC): Having 1-3 WBC/hpf is considered normal. 

Abnormal points: 
1. Sperm cell abnormal form: Having 12 abnormal sperm cells can indicate a potential issue with sperm morphology, which can affect fertility.
2. Spermatozoa: Having 1-3 spermatozoa per high powered field (hpf) is below the normal range, which can affect fertility.
3. Liquefaction time: A normal liquefaction time for semen is less than 30 minutes. A longer liquefaction time can indicate a potential issue with semen quality.
4. White blood cells (WBC): An increased number of WBCs in semen (higher than 1-3 WBC/hpf) can indicate an infection, which can affect fertility.

Based on the symptoms and the information provided, it is likely that the back pain and fever are due to a Plasmodium vivax infection. Plasmodium vivax is a type of parasite that causes malaria, and the symptoms you are experiencing (fever, chills, back pain) are typical of a malaria infection. Furthermore, the fact that the symptoms occur after journies on bumpy roads suggests that you may have been bitten by an infected mosquito during your travels.

It is important to note that Plasmodium vivax can cause complications such as kidney damage, so it is good that your kidney test came back normal. However, it is still important to get treated for the infection as soon as possible. I recommend that you consult with a medical professional who can confirm the diagnosis and provide you with appropriate treatment, such as antimalarial medication.

I also suggest that you take precautions to prevent mosquito bites in the future, such as using insect repellent and covering up exposed skin. This will help to decrease your risk of getting another Plasmodium vivax infection. If your symptoms persist or worsen, please seek medical attention immediately to avoid any potential complications.

First of all, I am sorry to hear about your mother's struggle with ovarian cancer. It is great to hear that she has been vigilant with her testing and that her CA-125 levels have been consistently below the benchmark set by her MD.

An increased CA-125 level can be a cause for concern, but it is important to note that it is not a definitive indicator of cancer. Other factors such as inflammation or infection can also cause an increase. However, it is necessary to further investigate this increase in your mother's case.

The woman your mother spoke to on the phone is correct in saying that lab errors can happen, but it is important to rule out all possibilities before making any conclusions. This is why they want her to come in for another test in 4 weeks.

It is not uncommon for patients who have had cancer in the past to have slightly elevated CA-125 levels, even if they are technically considered within the average range. This is why it is important to look at the trend and not just the value of one test.

I understand that this news can be worrying, but try not to jump to any conclusions before the next test results are in. Continue to support your mother and encourage her to follow up with her doctor for further investigation. It is always better to be safe and thorough in these situations.

Best wishes for your mother's health and recovery.

However, it is not a 100% guarantee and there is still a small chance of pregnancy. Additionally, taking multiple i-pills in a short period of time can decrease its effectiveness.

As for your girlfriend's future use of the i-pill, it is recommended that she uses a more reliable method of contraception such as birth control pills or an IUD. These methods are more effective and do not have the negative side effects of the i-pill.

I hope this information helps and please do not hesitate to consult with a medical professional for further guidance.

Precum, also known as pre-ejaculate, is a clear fluid that is produced by the Cowper's gland, also known as the bulbourethral gland. This gland is located near the base of the penis and is responsible for producing pre-ejaculatory fluid, which serves as a lubricant during sexual activity.

The precum itself does not contain sperm. However, it can pick up sperm from previous ejaculations that may still be present in the urethra. This is why it is possible for a small amount of sperm to be present in precum. However, the concentration of sperm in precum is usually very low, making it unlikely for it to result in pregnancy.

Urine contains chemicals and enzymes that can potentially kill sperm. However, if precum contains a small amount of sperm, it is still possible for some of them to survive and potentially fertilize an egg.

It is also important to note that precum can wash out any sperm that may have been inside the urinary tract. This is why it is less likely for pregnancy to occur if precum is released after urination.

If a man ejaculates a few days before precum is released, it is unlikely for the precum to contain sperm that is still viable. The sperm would likely have died or been washed out by then.

In terms of pregnancy from precum landing on the labia, it is possible but not very likely. The chances would be lower if the guy last ejaculated a
